Notes
New practical skills module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the molecular biology, biochemical and pharmacological-associated fields by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules.

This advanced practical module builds on previous practicals to develop further knowledge and practical skills in biomolecular and drug interactions by expanding on core techniques and practical skills complemented by bioinformatics and computational approaches; developing quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and applying critical analyses to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamentals of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessing and communicating practical experiments. Students will also be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest. 

The module comprises of 8 physical, practical sessions alongside 10 introductory plenary lectures and 4 workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This module will be assessed via two methods: 1. online problem-solving activities that will require analysis and interpretation of data involving quantitative and computational data-based problems 2. Group posters with an individual 200-word critical review of their practical investigation to demonstrate effective communication of research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
The prerequisites for this module are BIOS 101-106 (common year 1 Biosciences) and BIOS203 (common for all year 2 students in school)
Educational Aims
The module aims to develop students':

1. Knowledge and understanding of various practical techniques related to molecular biology, biochemistry and pharmacology.
2. Ability to plan and execute experiments and to use appropriate controls.
3. Proficiency in using bioinformatics tools to analyze gene and protein sequences and understand the roles of non-covalent interactions in the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give students hands-on experience in essential molecular biology, biochemical, and pharmacological-associated practical techniques through a series of interactive laboratory-based experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops. From recombinant DNA technology to protein expression, purification, enzyme kinetic assays, and drug interactions, this module covers a variety of techniques that students need to further their practical career within the Biosciences. Each topic is supported by bioinformatics/computational approaches and exercises to understand the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.

Students will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design while supplementing their wider theoretical learning by applying techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyze collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply their newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards their programme and fields of interest. 

The module comprises laboratory-based practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings. 

Learning and teaching are created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Students are assessed through an online exam (involving problem-solving activities) and a group poster to communicate the research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
Outline Syllabus
The workshops focus on helping students understand data analysis and relevant bioinformatics and may include but are not limited to the following topics:
Topic 1. Bioinformatics tools to analyse enzyme structure and active site using molecular modelling;

Topic 2. Structure-based drug design using computational protein-ligand docking and virtual drug screening; pharmaceutical techniques including drug-dose responses and drug-target interactions screening;

Topic 3. Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse gene sequences and design oligonucleotides, generation of protein chimera library using rapid sub cloning, ligation, and transformation;

Topic 4 Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse protein's structure and interactions; Data analysis using Bioinformatics, plotting and interpreting data.

Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills.

The practicals will cover various techniques employed in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology and may include but not be limited to the following topics:

Topic 1. Enzyme activity assay under a range of pH, temperature, and buffers;

Topic 2. Enzyme-substrate binding assay and enzyme kinetics assays, including Lineweaver-burke plot;

Topic 3. Inquiry-based drug metabolism studies- pharmaceutical techniques including enzyme inhibition kinetics (Km) and determining the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50);

Topic 4. Clinical drug toxicity using the drugs in current clinical practice;

Topic 5. Plasmid purification for DNA sequencing and restriction digestion analysed by agarose gel electrophoresis;

Topic 6. Affinity-tag purification of the overexpressed protein, protein concentration measurement, and sequencing data computational analysis;

Topic 7. Buffer exchange chromatography, protein separation using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, protein characterization (stability, aggregation, binding studies), and proteolytic cleavage;

Topic 8. Inquiry-based biophysics, effects of TEV protease cleavage, and protein interactions in different buffer conditions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week would be a one-hour lecture before the lab, 4 hours in the lab, and additional workshops for some weeks.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Nine synchronous research-focused lectures which will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills with examples from real-life scenarios. These will be delivered by the six research-active staff members

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: Nine F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in the laboratory. The demonstrators will be recruited for a group of 10 -12 students and each laboratory will have a staff member as an academic lead to support students' learning during the practical

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored


Teaching Method 3

Workshop Sessions: Four academic-led sessions that introduce students to various bioinformatics tools, support problem-based learning approaches to implementing computational biological tasks, data analyses & interpretation and visualization skills. Workshops are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and student’s questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators, with continuous feedback provided to the students.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student-directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organizational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes that are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of molecular biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, and bioinformatics to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlight how practical skills in research inform biotechnological advancement, scientific understanding, improvement of therapeutic strategies, and disease management.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques in this module will promote active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. The lectures and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding. Through formative exercises, students will receive valuable feedback and feedforward, identifying areas for improvement. This information can guide both staff and students in focusing on specific topics during workshops or individual study sessions.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative group work and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners can access advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. These are part of lab-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritize representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab environment, and focus on broader international collaboration to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with a focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessment components.
Various assessment modes are employed, keeping inclusivity and diversity in view.

The mode of assessments includes:

1. Analysis and interpretation of data (weighting 50%) 2-hour online exam involving quantitative and computational data-based problems. Open Book Resit allowed.

2. This will be a group poster (1000 words) with an additional 200-word individual critical review (weighting 50%) to evaluate, analyze, interpret, and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data from a subset of the practical experiments. (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

The group poster will be marked as a group (of 2-4 students), but a 200-word critical review will allow an individual mark to be assigned. Peer marking will also be included to ensure fairness in the contribution of the assessment. Resit will involve a group submission unless there is only one student, and they will submit an individual poster.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Preparing and presenting posters is highly authentic as it involves high-quality communication of scientific investigation to a broader audience and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, etc. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessments (i.e. practice online questions) or feedback will be provided for both assessments. The pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have a similar format and content as the original assessment but with substantial revision and will be submitted during the reassessment window. Resit for group poster will involve a group submission unless there is only one student and they will submit an individual poster. Resit marks will be capped at 40% (pass mark).
Learning materials will be available to students via the University's Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given.

Notes
New practical skills module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the molecular biology, biochemical and pharmacological-associated fields by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules.

This advanced practical module builds on previous practicals to develop further knowledge and practical skills in biomolecular and drug interactions by expanding on core techniques and practical skills complemented by bioinformatics and computational approaches; developing quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and applying critical analyses to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamentals of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessing and communicating practical experiments. Students will also be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest. 

The module comprises of 8 physical, practical sessions alongside 10 introductory plenary lectures and 4 workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This module will be assessed via two methods: 1. online problem-solving activities that will require analysis and interpretation of data involving quantitative and computational data-based problems 2. Group posters with an individual 200-word critical review of their practical investigation to demonstrate effective communication of research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
The prerequisites for this module are BIOS 101-106 (common year 1 Biosciences) and BIOS203 (common for all year 2 students in school)
Educational Aims
The module aims to develop students':

1. Knowledge and understanding of various practical techniques related to molecular biology, biochemistry and pharmacology.
2. Ability to plan and execute experiments and to use appropriate controls.
3. Proficiency in using bioinformatics tools to analyze gene and protein sequences and understand the roles of non-covalent interactions in the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give students hands-on experience in essential molecular biology, biochemical, and pharmacological-associated practical techniques through a series of interactive laboratory-based experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops. From recombinant DNA technology to protein expression, purification, enzyme kinetic assays, and drug interactions, this module covers a variety of techniques that students need to further their practical career within the Biosciences. Each topic is supported by bioinformatics/computational approaches and exercises to understand the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.

Students will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design while supplementing their wider theoretical learning by applying techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyze collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply their newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards their programme and fields of interest. 

The module comprises laboratory-based practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings. 

Learning and teaching are created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Students are assessed through an online exam (involving problem-solving activities) and a group poster to communicate the research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
Outline Syllabus
The workshops focus on helping students understand data analysis and relevant bioinformatics and may include but are not limited to the following topics:
Topic 1. Bioinformatics tools to analyse enzyme structure and active site using molecular modelling;

Topic 2. Structure-based drug design using computational protein-ligand docking and virtual drug screening; pharmaceutical techniques including drug-dose responses and drug-target interactions screening;

Topic 3. Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse gene sequences and design oligonucleotides, generation of protein chimera library using rapid sub cloning, ligation, and transformation;

Topic 4 Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse protein's structure and interactions; Data analysis using Bioinformatics, plotting and interpreting data.

Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills.

The practicals will cover various techniques employed in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology and may include but not be limited to the following topics:

Topic 1. Enzyme activity assay under a range of pH, temperature, and buffers;

Topic 2. Enzyme-substrate binding assay and enzyme kinetics assays, including Lineweaver-burke plot;

Topic 3. Inquiry-based drug metabolism studies- pharmaceutical techniques including enzyme inhibition kinetics (Km) and determining the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50);

Topic 4. Clinical drug toxicity using the drugs in current clinical practice;

Topic 5. Plasmid purification for DNA sequencing and restriction digestion analysed by agarose gel electrophoresis;

Topic 6. Affinity-tag purification of the overexpressed protein, protein concentration measurement, and sequencing data computational analysis;

Topic 7. Buffer exchange chromatography, protein separation using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, protein characterization (stability, aggregation, binding studies), and proteolytic cleavage;

Topic 8. Inquiry-based biophysics, effects of TEV protease cleavage, and protein interactions in different buffer conditions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week would be a one-hour lecture before the lab, 4 hours in the lab, and additional workshops for some weeks.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Nine synchronous research-focused lectures which will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills with examples from real-life scenarios. These will be delivered by the six research-active staff members

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: Nine F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in the laboratory. The demonstrators will be recruited for a group of 10 -12 students and each laboratory will have a staff member as an academic lead to support students' learning during the practical

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored


Teaching Method 3

Workshop Sessions: Four academic-led sessions that introduce students to various bioinformatics tools, support problem-based learning approaches to implementing computational biological tasks, data analyses & interpretation and visualization skills. Workshops are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and student’s questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators, with continuous feedback provided to the students.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student-directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organizational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes that are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of molecular biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, and bioinformatics to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlight how practical skills in research inform biotechnological advancement, scientific understanding, improvement of therapeutic strategies, and disease management.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques in this module will promote active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. The lectures and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding. Through formative exercises, students will receive valuable feedback and feedforward, identifying areas for improvement. This information can guide both staff and students in focusing on specific topics during workshops or individual study sessions.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative group work and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners can access advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. These are part of lab-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritize representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab environment, and focus on broader international collaboration to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with a focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessment components.
Various assessment modes are employed, keeping inclusivity and diversity in view.

The mode of assessments includes:

1. Analysis and interpretation of data (weighting 50%) 2-hour online exam involving quantitative and computational data-based problems. Open Book Resit allowed.

2. This will be a group poster (1000 words) with an additional 200-word individual critical review (weighting 50%) to evaluate, analyze, interpret, and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data from a subset of the practical experiments. (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

The group poster will be marked as a group (of 2-4 students), but a 200-word critical review will allow an individual mark to be assigned. Peer marking will also be included to ensure fairness in the contribution of the assessment. Resit will involve a group submission unless there is only one student, and they will submit an individual poster.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Preparing and presenting posters is highly authentic as it involves high-quality communication of scientific investigation to a broader audience and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, etc. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessments (i.e. practice online questions) or feedback will be provided for both assessments. The pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have a similar format and content as the original assessment but with substantial revision and will be submitted during the reassessment window. Resit for group poster will involve a group submission unless there is only one student and they will submit an individual poster. Resit marks will be capped at 40% (pass mark).
Learning materials will be available to students via the University's Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given.

Notes
New practical skills module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the molecular biology, biochemical and pharmacological-associated fields by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules.

This advanced practical module builds on previous practicals to develop further knowledge and practical skills in biomolecular and drug interactions by expanding on core techniques and practical skills complemented by bioinformatics and computational approaches; developing quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and applying critical analyses to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamentals of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessing and communicating practical experiments. Students will also be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest. 

The module comprises of 8 physical, practical sessions alongside 10 introductory plenary lectures and 4 workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This module will be assessed via two methods: 1. online problem-solving activities that will require analysis and interpretation of data involving quantitative and computational data-based problems 2. Group posters with an individual 200-word critical review of their practical investigation to demonstrate effective communication of research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
The prerequisites for this module are BIOS 101-106 (common year 1 Biosciences) and BIOS203 (common for all year 2 students in school)
Educational Aims
The module aims to develop students':

1. Knowledge and understanding of various practical techniques related to molecular biology, biochemistry and pharmacology.
2. Ability to plan and execute experiments and to use appropriate controls.
3. Proficiency in using bioinformatics tools to analyze gene and protein sequences and understand the roles of non-covalent interactions in the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give students hands-on experience in essential molecular biology, biochemical, and pharmacological-associated practical techniques through a series of interactive laboratory-based experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops. From recombinant DNA technology to protein expression, purification, enzyme kinetic assays, and drug interactions, this module covers a variety of techniques that students need to further their practical career within the Biosciences. Each topic is supported by bioinformatics/computational approaches and exercises to understand the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.

Students will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design while supplementing their wider theoretical learning by applying techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyze collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply their newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards their programme and fields of interest. 

The module comprises laboratory-based practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings. 

Learning and teaching are created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Students are assessed through an online exam (involving problem-solving activities) and a group poster to communicate the research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
Outline Syllabus
The workshops focus on helping students understand data analysis and relevant bioinformatics and may include but are not limited to the following topics:
Topic 1. Bioinformatics tools to analyse enzyme structure and active site using molecular modelling;

Topic 2. Structure-based drug design using computational protein-ligand docking and virtual drug screening; pharmaceutical techniques including drug-dose responses and drug-target interactions screening;

Topic 3. Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse gene sequences and design oligonucleotides, generation of protein chimera library using rapid sub cloning, ligation, and transformation;

Topic 4 Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse protein's structure and interactions; Data analysis using Bioinformatics, plotting and interpreting data.

Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills.

The practicals will cover various techniques employed in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology and may include but not be limited to the following topics:

Topic 1. Enzyme activity assay under a range of pH, temperature, and buffers;

Topic 2. Enzyme-substrate binding assay and enzyme kinetics assays, including Lineweaver-burke plot;

Topic 3. Inquiry-based drug metabolism studies- pharmaceutical techniques including enzyme inhibition kinetics (Km) and determining the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50);

Topic 4. Clinical drug toxicity using the drugs in current clinical practice;

Topic 5. Plasmid purification for DNA sequencing and restriction digestion analysed by agarose gel electrophoresis;

Topic 6. Affinity-tag purification of the overexpressed protein, protein concentration measurement, and sequencing data computational analysis;

Topic 7. Buffer exchange chromatography, protein separation using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, protein characterization (stability, aggregation, binding studies), and proteolytic cleavage;

Topic 8. Inquiry-based biophysics, effects of TEV protease cleavage, and protein interactions in different buffer conditions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week would be a one-hour lecture before the lab, 4 hours in the lab, and additional workshops for some weeks.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Nine synchronous research-focused lectures which will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills with examples from real-life scenarios. These will be delivered by the six research-active staff members

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: Nine F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in the laboratory. The demonstrators will be recruited for a group of 10 -12 students and each laboratory will have a staff member as an academic lead to support students' learning during the practical

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored


Teaching Method 3

Workshop Sessions: Four academic-led sessions that introduce students to various bioinformatics tools, support problem-based learning approaches to implementing computational biological tasks, data analyses & interpretation and visualization skills. Workshops are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and student’s questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators, with continuous feedback provided to the students.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student-directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organizational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes that are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of molecular biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, and bioinformatics to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlight how practical skills in research inform biotechnological advancement, scientific understanding, improvement of therapeutic strategies, and disease management.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques in this module will promote active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. The lectures and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding. Through formative exercises, students will receive valuable feedback and feedforward, identifying areas for improvement. This information can guide both staff and students in focusing on specific topics during workshops or individual study sessions.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative group work and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners can access advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. These are part of lab-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritize representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab environment, and focus on broader international collaboration to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with a focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessment components.
Various assessment modes are employed, keeping inclusivity and diversity in view.

The mode of assessments includes:

1. Analysis and interpretation of data (weighting 50%) 2-hour online exam involving quantitative and computational data-based problems. Open Book Resit allowed.

2. This will be a group poster (1000 words) with an additional 200-word individual critical review (weighting 50%) to evaluate, analyze, interpret, and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data from a subset of the practical experiments. (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

The group poster will be marked as a group (of 2-4 students), but a 200-word critical review will allow an individual mark to be assigned. Peer marking will also be included to ensure fairness in the contribution of the assessment. Resit will involve a group submission unless there is only one student, and they will submit an individual poster.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Preparing and presenting posters is highly authentic as it involves high-quality communication of scientific investigation to a broader audience and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, etc. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessments (i.e. practice online questions) or feedback will be provided for both assessments. The pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have a similar format and content as the original assessment but with substantial revision and will be submitted during the reassessment window. Resit for group poster will involve a group submission unless there is only one student and they will submit an individual poster. Resit marks will be capped at 40% (pass mark).
Learning materials will be available to students via the University's Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given.

Notes
New practical skills module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the molecular biology, biochemical and pharmacological-associated fields by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules.

This advanced practical module builds on previous practicals to develop further knowledge and practical skills in biomolecular and drug interactions by expanding on core techniques and practical skills complemented by bioinformatics and computational approaches; developing quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and applying critical analyses to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamentals of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessing and communicating practical experiments. Students will also be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest. 

The module comprises of 8 physical, practical sessions alongside 10 introductory plenary lectures and 4 workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This module will be assessed via two methods: 1. online problem-solving activities that will require analysis and interpretation of data involving quantitative and computational data-based problems 2. Group posters with an individual 200-word critical review of their practical investigation to demonstrate effective communication of research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
The prerequisites for this module are BIOS 101-106 (common year 1 Biosciences) and BIOS203 (common for all year 2 students in school)
Educational Aims
The module aims to develop students':

1. Knowledge and understanding of various practical techniques related to molecular biology, biochemistry and pharmacology.
2. Ability to plan and execute experiments and to use appropriate controls.
3. Proficiency in using bioinformatics tools to analyze gene and protein sequences and understand the roles of non-covalent interactions in the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give students hands-on experience in essential molecular biology, biochemical, and pharmacological-associated practical techniques through a series of interactive laboratory-based experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops. From recombinant DNA technology to protein expression, purification, enzyme kinetic assays, and drug interactions, this module covers a variety of techniques that students need to further their practical career within the Biosciences. Each topic is supported by bioinformatics/computational approaches and exercises to understand the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.

Students will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design while supplementing their wider theoretical learning by applying techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyze collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply their newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards their programme and fields of interest. 

The module comprises laboratory-based practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings. 

Learning and teaching are created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Students are assessed through an online exam (involving problem-solving activities) and a group poster to communicate the research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
Outline Syllabus
The workshops focus on helping students understand data analysis and relevant bioinformatics and may include but are not limited to the following topics:
Topic 1. Bioinformatics tools to analyse enzyme structure and active site using molecular modelling;

Topic 2. Structure-based drug design using computational protein-ligand docking and virtual drug screening; pharmaceutical techniques including drug-dose responses and drug-target interactions screening;

Topic 3. Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse gene sequences and design oligonucleotides, generation of protein chimera library using rapid sub cloning, ligation, and transformation;

Topic 4 Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse protein's structure and interactions; Data analysis using Bioinformatics, plotting and interpreting data.

Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills.

The practicals will cover various techniques employed in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology and may include but not be limited to the following topics:

Topic 1. Enzyme activity assay under a range of pH, temperature, and buffers;

Topic 2. Enzyme-substrate binding assay and enzyme kinetics assays, including Lineweaver-burke plot;

Topic 3. Inquiry-based drug metabolism studies- pharmaceutical techniques including enzyme inhibition kinetics (Km) and determining the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50);

Topic 4. Clinical drug toxicity using the drugs in current clinical practice;

Topic 5. Plasmid purification for DNA sequencing and restriction digestion analysed by agarose gel electrophoresis;

Topic 6. Affinity-tag purification of the overexpressed protein, protein concentration measurement, and sequencing data computational analysis;

Topic 7. Buffer exchange chromatography, protein separation using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, protein characterization (stability, aggregation, binding studies), and proteolytic cleavage;

Topic 8. Inquiry-based biophysics, effects of TEV protease cleavage, and protein interactions in different buffer conditions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week would be a one-hour lecture before the lab, 4 hours in the lab, and additional workshops for some weeks.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Nine synchronous research-focused lectures which will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills with examples from real-life scenarios. These will be delivered by the six research-active staff members

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: Nine F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in the laboratory. The demonstrators will be recruited for a group of 10 -12 students and each laboratory will have a staff member as an academic lead to support students' learning during the practical

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored


Teaching Method 3

Workshop Sessions: Four academic-led sessions that introduce students to various bioinformatics tools, support problem-based learning approaches to implementing computational biological tasks, data analyses & interpretation and visualization skills. Workshops are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and student’s questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators, with continuous feedback provided to the students.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student-directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organizational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes that are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of molecular biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, and bioinformatics to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlight how practical skills in research inform biotechnological advancement, scientific understanding, improvement of therapeutic strategies, and disease management.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques in this module will promote active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. The lectures and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding. Through formative exercises, students will receive valuable feedback and feedforward, identifying areas for improvement. This information can guide both staff and students in focusing on specific topics during workshops or individual study sessions.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative group work and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners can access advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. These are part of lab-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritize representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab environment, and focus on broader international collaboration to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with a focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessment components.
Various assessment modes are employed, keeping inclusivity and diversity in view.

The mode of assessments includes:

1. Analysis and interpretation of data (weighting 50%) 2-hour online exam involving quantitative and computational data-based problems. Open Book Resit allowed.

2. This will be a group poster (1000 words) with an additional 200-word individual critical review (weighting 50%) to evaluate, analyze, interpret, and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data from a subset of the practical experiments. (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

The group poster will be marked as a group (of 2-4 students), but a 200-word critical review will allow an individual mark to be assigned. Peer marking will also be included to ensure fairness in the contribution of the assessment. Resit will involve a group submission unless there is only one student, and they will submit an individual poster.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Preparing and presenting posters is highly authentic as it involves high-quality communication of scientific investigation to a broader audience and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, etc. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessments (i.e. practice online questions) or feedback will be provided for both assessments. The pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have a similar format and content as the original assessment but with substantial revision and will be submitted during the reassessment window. Resit for group poster will involve a group submission unless there is only one student and they will submit an individual poster. Resit marks will be capped at 40% (pass mark).
Learning materials will be available to students via the University's Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given.

Notes
New practical skills module as part of programme revalidation. Due to commence September 2025, starting with year 2.

Overview

Overview
This practical module aims to enhance and develop practical and analytical skills related to the molecular biology, biochemical and pharmacological-associated fields by building on experiences gained in previous practical modules.

This advanced practical module builds on previous practicals to develop further knowledge and practical skills in biomolecular and drug interactions by expanding on core techniques and practical skills complemented by bioinformatics and computational approaches; developing quantitative and qualitative research practices, data handling and applying critical analyses to experimental research problems. Students will learn the fundamentals of experimental design and the essential statistical and mathematical methods necessary for assessing and communicating practical experiments. Students will also be able to tailor their practical learning to focus on research problems associated with their programme of study or fields of interest. 

The module comprises of 8 physical, practical sessions alongside 10 introductory plenary lectures and 4 workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings.  This module will be assessed via two methods: 1. online problem-solving activities that will require analysis and interpretation of data involving quantitative and computational data-based problems 2. Group posters with an individual 200-word critical review of their practical investigation to demonstrate effective communication of research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
The prerequisites for this module are BIOS 101-106 (common year 1 Biosciences) and BIOS203 (common for all year 2 students in school)
Educational Aims
The module aims to develop students':

1. Knowledge and understanding of various practical techniques related to molecular biology, biochemistry and pharmacology.
2. Ability to plan and execute experiments and to use appropriate controls.
3. Proficiency in using bioinformatics tools to analyze gene and protein sequences and understand the roles of non-covalent interactions in the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This practical skills module is designed to give students hands-on experience in essential molecular biology, biochemical, and pharmacological-associated practical techniques through a series of interactive laboratory-based experimental sessions and live synchronous workshops. From recombinant DNA technology to protein expression, purification, enzyme kinetic assays, and drug interactions, this module covers a variety of techniques that students need to further their practical career within the Biosciences. Each topic is supported by bioinformatics/computational approaches and exercises to understand the structure and function of enzymes, proteins, and drug interactions.

Students will also learn the underpinning knowledge behind some of the methodologies and the intricacies of experimental design while supplementing their wider theoretical learning by applying techniques to tackle problems across the Biosciences disciplines. Students will learn how to analyze collected data and communicate the findings effectively, with the opportunity to apply their newly acquired skills to research projects tailored towards their programme and fields of interest. 

The module comprises laboratory-based practical sessions alongside introductory plenary lectures and workshops, using active-learning delivery methods to ensure students can understand, synthesize, evaluate and communicate their research findings. 

Learning and teaching are created and delivered by research-active scientists, ensuring that teaching is informed by the latest research and advances and is designed to be accessible, inclusive, and representative.

Students are assessed through an online exam (involving problem-solving activities) and a group poster to communicate the research outputs through scientific writing and graphical presentations.
Outline Syllabus
The workshops focus on helping students understand data analysis and relevant bioinformatics and may include but are not limited to the following topics:
Topic 1. Bioinformatics tools to analyse enzyme structure and active site using molecular modelling;

Topic 2. Structure-based drug design using computational protein-ligand docking and virtual drug screening; pharmaceutical techniques including drug-dose responses and drug-target interactions screening;

Topic 3. Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse gene sequences and design oligonucleotides, generation of protein chimera library using rapid sub cloning, ligation, and transformation;

Topic 4 Introduction to bioinformatics tools to analyse protein's structure and interactions; Data analysis using Bioinformatics, plotting and interpreting data.

Synchronous research focused lectures will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills.

The practicals will cover various techniques employed in the fields of molecular biology, biochemistry, and pharmacology and may include but not be limited to the following topics:

Topic 1. Enzyme activity assay under a range of pH, temperature, and buffers;

Topic 2. Enzyme-substrate binding assay and enzyme kinetics assays, including Lineweaver-burke plot;

Topic 3. Inquiry-based drug metabolism studies- pharmaceutical techniques including enzyme inhibition kinetics (Km) and determining the half maximal inhibitory concentration (IC 50);

Topic 4. Clinical drug toxicity using the drugs in current clinical practice;

Topic 5. Plasmid purification for DNA sequencing and restriction digestion analysed by agarose gel electrophoresis;

Topic 6. Affinity-tag purification of the overexpressed protein, protein concentration measurement, and sequencing data computational analysis;

Topic 7. Buffer exchange chromatography, protein separation using polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis, protein characterization (stability, aggregation, binding studies), and proteolytic cleavage;

Topic 8. Inquiry-based biophysics, effects of TEV protease cleavage, and protein interactions in different buffer conditions.
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week would be a one-hour lecture before the lab, 4 hours in the lab, and additional workshops for some weeks.

Teaching Method 1

Lectures: Nine synchronous research-focused lectures which will cover introductory material and context to the practical skills and application of taught & experimental skills with examples from real-life scenarios. These will be delivered by the six research-active staff members

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2

Laboratory Work: Nine F2F practical sessions designed to develop & enhance laboratory/experimental skills in the laboratory. The demonstrators will be recruited for a group of 10 -12 students and each laboratory will have a staff member as an academic lead to support students' learning during the practical

Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3

Interactive Materials: Interactive virtual lab resources, simulations and videos that allow students to familiarise themselves with different lab skills and use equipment and scientific procedures within their own time and space, allowing for inclusivity & diversity.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored

Teaching Method 4

Asynchronous lecture recordings: Introduce applied quantitative skills to practical problem solving. To include a variety of data handling, statistical and data visualisation methodologies.

Attendance Recorded: No, engagement monitored


Teaching Method 3

Workshop Sessions: Four academic-led sessions that introduce students to various bioinformatics tools, support problem-based learning approaches to implementing computational biological tasks, data analyses & interpretation and visualization skills. Workshops are delivered online or synchronously by lecturers and student’s questions are addressed by lecturers and demonstrators, with continuous feedback provided to the students.

Attendance Recorded: Yes

The student-directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading, completion of workbooks, accessing online resources, searching the literature and critically appraising articles. This will require adaptability & organizational skills.

Liverpool Curriculum and the Liverpool Hallmarks are at the centre of this module as evidenced by the cohesive research-connected programme we have designed where learning outcomes will be evaluated with authentic assessments that directly relate to activities performed by professional experts in the field. This module contributes to programmes that are specifically designed to support students for future careers in Biosciences:

Research-connected teaching: Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists in the field of molecular biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, and bioinformatics to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research evidence. Core concepts are contextualized with evidence-based publications of recent clinical and scientific research and application-based sessions/workshops, which highlight how practical skills in research inform biotechnological advancement, scientific understanding, improvement of therapeutic strategies, and disease management.

Inclusivity and accessibility: Development of practical experience to be accessible and inclusive for all individuals. Self-directed learning, using interactive resources will allow students to prepare for sessions and gain an understanding of practical elements before attending. Resource templates use accessible design schemes. Content is uploaded to the VLE in advance, in a format compatible with assistive technologies and checked proactively with Ally. Format adjustments are also available on request in accordance with specific learning disabilities and support plans.

Active learning: Practical and experimental techniques in this module will promote active learning through observation, skill acquisition and application. The lectures and workshops will be made engaging through interactive strategies. Utilizing tools such as PollEverywhere, Mentimeter, and Kahoot for quizzes, as well as collaborative platforms like Padlet and Miro, will create a dynamic learning environment. These resources will offer prompts for group discussions on various concepts, fostering deeper understanding. Through formative exercises, students will receive valuable feedback and feedforward, identifying areas for improvement. This information can guide both staff and students in focusing on specific topics during workshops or individual study sessions.

Confidence: Confidence is developed continuously throughout the module. Lectures are discursive and interactive, with learners contributing ideas and analysis to ongoing discussion. Practical sessions involve collaborative group work and experimental learning. Learners work as part of a team to plan and carry out complex technical work, under expert supervision. This builds confidence by creating a ‘safe space’ for sharing ideas and expertise. Successfully completing a practical session builds confidence in technical skills.

Digital fluency: Digital fluency is encouraged through a combination of methods. Learners can access advanced digital resources, programmes and analytical tools to assist in data analyses. These are part of lab-based practical analyses and independent learning to consolidate practical and theoretical knowledge. Digital technology is embedded into practical teaching with the use of experimental applications, methodologies and practices that learners can explore in their own time.

Global citizenship: Biosciences is a globally connected professional community. Learning and assessment activities embed values of inclusivity, equality and sustainability. In learning materials, we prioritize representation and use scientific cases of diverse and underrepresented communities, focus on sustainable practices within the lab environment, and focus on broader international collaboration to achieve goals. There is a strong ethical focus within the school that empowers learners to take personal responsibility for the human impact of their actions, with a focus on practical related ethics.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via two assessment components.
Various assessment modes are employed, keeping inclusivity and diversity in view.

The mode of assessments includes:

1. Analysis and interpretation of data (weighting 50%) 2-hour online exam involving quantitative and computational data-based problems. Open Book Resit allowed.

2. This will be a group poster (1000 words) with an additional 200-word individual critical review (weighting 50%) to evaluate, analyze, interpret, and communicate qualitative/ quantitative data from a subset of the practical experiments. (Research connected teaching - Liverpool Curriculum). Resit allowed.

The group poster will be marked as a group (of 2-4 students), but a 200-word critical review will allow an individual mark to be assigned. Peer marking will also be included to ensure fairness in the contribution of the assessment. Resit will involve a group submission unless there is only one student, and they will submit an individual poster.

Authentic assessment: There are two assessment components. The online test requires students to lead their own inquiry of the content and build a critical knowledge base that will be applied to subsequent modules. Preparing and presenting posters is highly authentic as it involves high-quality communication of scientific investigation to a broader audience and offers a comprehensive assessment of knowledge in different authentic contexts – problem-solving, critical thinking, etc. This fosters skills desirable in many sectors of employment and those of lifelong learning.

Formative assessments (i.e. practice online questions) or feedback will be provided for both assessments. The pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Resit strategy: Resit opportunity will be given to the assessments specified where a resit is available. The resit will have a similar format and content as the original assessment but with substantial revision and will be submitted during the reassessment window. Resit for group poster will involve a group submission unless there is only one student and they will submit an individual poster. Resit marks will be capped at 40% (pass mark).
Learning materials will be available to students via the University's Virtual Learning environment. Details of the assessments are in the table below.

Students will be informed that in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that are deemed necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed of any such changes so that approval can be given.
